<h2 class="topic-title"><a href="./viewtopic.php?f=3&amp;t=5572&amp;start=50">2015 Applicant Profiles and Admission Results</a></h2>
<!-- NOTE: remove the style="display: none" when you want to have the forum description on the topic body -->
<div style="display: none !important;"><ul><li>This has become our largest and most active forum because the physics GRE is just one aspect of getting accepted into a graduate physics program.</li><li>There are applications, personal statements, letters of recommendation, visiting schools, anxiety of waiting for acceptances, deciding between schools, finding out where others are going, etc.</li></ul><br /></div>

																											      	    <h3 class="first"><a href="#p48669">Re: 2015 Applicant Profiles and Admission Results</a></h3>


																																				      <p class="author"><a href="./viewtopic.php?p=48669#p48669"><span class="imageset icon_post_target" title="Post">Post</span></a><span class="responsive-hide">by <strong><a href="./memberlist.php?mode=viewprofile&amp;u=19927" class="username">drumminskillz</a></strong> &raquo; </span>Thu Jan 15, 2015 5:58 pm </p>



																																							       <div class="content">Undergrad Institution: Small private university, not known for physics<br />Major(s): Physics<br />Minor(s): Mathematics<br />GPA in Major: 4.0/4.0<br />Overall GPA: 3.6/4.0<br />Length of Degree: Switch majors, so did physics in 3 years.<br />Position in Class: Top physics student<br />Type of Student: Male white domestic<br /><br />GRE Scores : (revised or old version?)<br />Q:170 (98%)<br />V:160 (84%)<br />W:4.0 (56%)<br />P:650 (40%) &lt;- I took the PGRE before taking most of my upper level physics courses.<br /><br /><br /><br />Research Experience: 2.5 years of research in various fields, including work at Fermilab.<br /><br />Awards/Honors/Recognitions: Dean's list, nothing special.<br /><br />Pertinent Activities or Jobs: Tutor, TA for several classes, SPS President<br /><br />Any Miscellaneous Accomplishments that Might Help:<br /><br />Special Bonus Points: <br /><br />Any Other Info That Shows Up On Your App and Might Matter: Took entire physics curriculum in 3 years.<br /><br />Applying to Where:<br /><br />All Condensed Matter Experimental:<br /><br />Stanford- <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected 2/17</span><br />UCSB- <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected 2/24</span><br />UCLA-<br />UC Irvine<br />Colorado Boulder-<br />UW Madison- <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected 2/2</span><br />University of Illinois (Champaign/Urbana)-<br />Iowa State- <span style="color: #00FF00">Accepted 2/13 ($1900/month for 9 months TA)</span><br />Mizzou-<br />Vanderbilt-<br />Notre Dame-<br />Purdue- <span style="color: #00FF00">Accepted 1/21 ($18.6k/9 months TA + $1.7k over the summer)</span></div>

																																																																																							   	 <h3 ><a href="#p48674">Re: 2015 Applicant Profiles and Admission Results</a></h3>


																																																																																														      <p class="author"><a href="./viewtopic.php?p=48674#p48674"><span class="imageset icon_post_target" title="Post">Post</span></a><span class="responsive-hide">by <strong><a href="./memberlist.php?mode=viewprofile&amp;u=19928" class="username">hari00968</a></strong> &raquo; </span>Fri Jan 16, 2015 4:26 am </p>



																																																																																																	       <div class="content"><span style="font-weight: bold">Undergrad Institution</span>: Indian technical institute. Well known for engineering, top in the country for engineering, physics.<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Major(s)</span>: Engineering (interdisciplinary)<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Minor(s)</span>: Physics <br /><span style="font-weight: bold">GPA in Major</span>: 8.8/10<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Overall GPA</span>: 8.64/10<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Length of Degree</span>: 5 years<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Position in Class</span>: Near top<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Type of Student</span>: International male.<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">GRE Scores</span> : (revised)<br />Q: 170 (98th percentile)<br />V: 162 (89th percentile)<br />W: 5.0 (94th percentile)<br />P: 990 (94th percentile)<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">TOEFL Total</span>: 113/120 (iBT)<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Research Experience</span>: 12 months, at the physics department in my school. Details - <br />Computational condensed matter physics - 6 months - conference poster presentation.<br />Computatonal materials science - 6 months - conference, published in proceedings.<br />Computational solid mechanics - 3 months - no conference/publication.<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Awards/Honors/Recognitions</span>: None.<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Pertinent Activities or Jobs</span>: TA for a sophomore course, 6 months.<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Any Miscellaneous Accomplishments that Might Help</span>: None.<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Special Bonus Points</span>: Graduate level courses in condensed matter physics, mathematical physics.<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Any Other Info That Shows Up On Your App and Might Matter</span>: Strong extra-curriculars? <br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Applying to Where</span>: (Mostly materials science departments with a research focus on CMP/faculty from physics)<br /><br />U of British Columbia - Engineering Physics - CMP th/exp - <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected</span><br />U of Virginia - Engineering Physics - CMP exp - <span style="color: #00BF00">11/02 - Accepted to the PhD program! RA, $22,500 first two years, $24,000 after.</span><br />Cornell - Materials Science - CMP th/exp (Master's) - <span style="color: #00BF00">23/02 - Accepted without funding.</span><br />Penn State - Materials Science - CMP exp (Master's) - <span style="color: #00BF40"><span style="font-weight: bold">Accepted with funding into MS/PhD program. RA, $27,000 p.a. Attending! </span></span><br />UT Austin - Materials Science - CMP th/exp - <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected</span><br />UMich Ann Arbor - Materials Science - CMP th/exp - <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected</span><br />UIUC - Materials Science - CMP th/exp - <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected</span><br />ENS Lyon (Erasmus Mundus ATOSIM) - Computational Physics - <span style="color: #00BF00">03/07 - Accepted, with funding. </span><br />______________________________________________<br /><br />Since my undergraduate major is in engineering, and I have neither a perfect GPA nor any publications, the selectivity of graduate programs in physics makes it impossible to get into any of the well known schools. However, I have found that several physics faculty members working in CMP (mostly experimental, in rare cases theory) are also part of their respective schools' materials science departments. I hope that by applying to engineering physics/materials science graduate programs, my engineering background wouldn't be as much of a deterrent to admissions committees.<br /><br />UPDATE - Worked! Having joined a graduate program in Materials Science, I see there is ample scope to work in experimental condensed matter physics, despite not formally belonging to the department of Physics. I assume it would be similar in other schools.</div>

																																																																																																																																																   	 <h3 ><a href="#p48680">Re: 2015 Applicant Profiles and Admission Results</a></h3>


																																																																																																																																																							      <p class="author"><a href="./viewtopic.php?p=48680#p48680"><span class="imageset icon_post_target" title="Post">Post</span></a><span class="responsive-hide">by <strong><a href="./memberlist.php?mode=viewprofile&amp;u=19930" class="username">Rotenberg</a></strong> &raquo; </span>Fri Jan 16, 2015 11:31 pm </p>



																																																																																																																																																										       <div class="content"><span style="font-weight: bold">Undergrad Institution</span>: Missouri University of Science and Technology (formerly University of Missouri-Rolla)... mainly engineering, probably not much of a reputation in physics.<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Major(s)</span>: Physics<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Minor(s)</span>: Mathematics<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">GPA in Major</span>: 4.00<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Overall GPA</span>: 4.00<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Length of Degree</span>: 4 years<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Position in Class</span>: Top<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Type of Student</span>: Domestic white male<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">GRE Scores </span>: (revised)<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Q</span>: 170 (98%)<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">V</span>: 169 (99%)<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">W</span>: 3.5 (38%)<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">P</span>: 980 (93%)<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Research Experience</span>: In the middle of two semesters of senior lab class research projects. That's it. <img class="smilies" src="./images/smilies/icon_sad.gif" alt=":(" title="Sad" /><br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Awards/Honors/Recognitions</span>: Dean's List, Academic Scholar's List<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Pertinent Activities or Jobs</span>: Tutored math and physics one semester, SPS member<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Any Miscellaneous Accomplishments that Might Help</span>: Lots of programming experience (personal and professional) in several languages.<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Special Bonus Points</span>: Taking a semester of graduate-level quantum mechanics.<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Any Other Info That Shows Up On Your App and Might Matter</span>: I have a fairly non-traditional academic history--dropped out of high school, took the GED, and attended two community colleges full time before transferring.<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Applying to Where</span>:<br /><br /><span style="text-decoration: underline">MIT</span> - Physics - HEP/Astro/Cosmology Theory - <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected via email 2/18</span><br /><span style="text-decoration: underline">Harvard</span> - Physics - HEP/Astro/Cosmology Theory - <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected via website 3/2</span><br /><span style="text-decoration: underline">Caltech</span> - Physics - HEP/Astro/Cosmology Theory - <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected via email 2/23</span><br /><span style="text-decoration: underline">Stanford</span> - Physics - HEP/Astro/Cosmology Theory - <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected via email 2/17</span><br /><span style="text-decoration: underline">UC Berkeley</span> - Physics - HEP/Astro/Cosmology Theory - <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected via website 3/12</span><br /><span style="text-decoration: underline">Princeton</span> - Physics - HEP/Astro/Cosmology Theory - <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected via email 2/19</span><br /><span style="text-decoration: underline">Chicago</span> - Physics - HEP/Astro/Cosmology Theory - <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected via email 3/3</span><br /><span style="text-decoration: underline">University of Washington</span> - Physics - HEP/Astro/Cosmology Theory - <span style="color: #40BF00">Accepted via email 1/29 - TA and $4k scholarship = $1500 + $1956/mo.</span> - Accepted offer 3/13 - Will attend<br /><span style="text-decoration: underline">CU-Boulder</span> - Physics - HEP/Astro/Cosmology Theory - <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected via email 3/11</span><br /><span style="text-decoration: underline">Washington University in St. Louis</span> - Physics - HEP/Astro/Cosmology Theory - <span style="color: #40BF00">Accepted via email 1/30 - $25,500/yr fellowship for 3 years + $8,500 for one summer</span> - Declined offer 3/13<br /><span style="text-decoration: underline">Cambridge</span> - Applied Mathematics and Theoretical Physics (MASt.) - HEP/Astro/Cosmology Theory - <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected via website 2/11</span><br /><span style="text-decoration: underline">British Columbia</span> - Physics (M.Sc.) - HEP/Astro/Cosmology Theory - <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected via email 3/12</span><br /><br /><br />Captain Obvious says: HEP-th is hard. Shows that you can get accepted at respectable places without any actual research experience, though (not that I recommend trying to)</div>

Big foreign public University, strong reputation for physics<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Major(s)</span>: Theoretical Particle Physics<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Minor(s)</span>:<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">GPA in Major</span>: 91.4/100<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Overall GPA</span>:<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Length of Degree</span>: 2<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Position in Class</span>: Top<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Type of Student</span>: International Male<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">GRE Scores</span>: revised<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Q</span>: 169 (97%)<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">V</span>: 159 (81%)<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">W</span>: 4.5 (80%)<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">P</span>: 960 (91%)<br /><br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">TOEFL Total</span>: 118<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Research Experience</span>: at my Master's institution, 2 years of research experience. 2 papers, one accepted by PRD and chosen for an Editors' Suggestion (yay! they said it was really interesting and well written) and one submitted for publication. Two poster presentations at a workshop and a Winter School. Since I finished my Master's in December I am spending the period of time until Fall 2015 as a visiting student at a very important research institute in Europe, the Niels Bohr Institute, doing research with a visiting Professor from Oxford.<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Awards/Honors/Recognitions</span>: various within my school and college (such as &quot;you have good marks&quot; stuff), plus a recognition the ministry of public education in Italy and a prestigious scholarship from the government of Australia. Graduated with 110/110 from my Undergraduate institution and with First Class Honours from my Master's one.<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Pertinent Activities or Jobs</span>: tutor in College and at the University, laboratory demonstrator, Postgraduate Physics Students' Society Secretary, engaged in a lot of outreach, good programming skills.<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Any Miscellaneous Accomplishments that Might Help</span>: Master's thesis was awarded a very high mark, hold a violin diploma, speak 3 languages, lived in several different countries (hopefully can help on diversity statement), attended various workshops, attended two Winter Schools recently.<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Special Bonus Points</span>: three very famous recommenders with very good connections in most of the places where I applied to.<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Any Other Info That Shows Up On Your App and Might Matter</span>: spent some time on exchange at Imperial College and now working at the Niels Bohr Institute with a visiting Professor from Oxford. I think my recommendations are very strong and people have told me my SoP was very well written. Mentioned 3-4 Professors I wanted to work with in my SoP, and was very specific about parts of their research I'm interested in, I read their papers very carefully. Also kept an open mind mentioning other opportunities should these Professors not be available. 																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																		      <p class="author"><a href="./viewtopic.php?p=48685#p48685"><span class="imageset icon_post_target" title="Post">Post</span></a><span class="responsive-hide">by <strong><a href="./memberlist.php?mode=viewprofile&amp;u=16784" class="username">myjlt</a></strong> &raquo; </span>Sun Jan 18, 2015 8:46 pm </p>



																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																					       <div class="content">Undergrad Institution: Ivy<br />Major(s): Physics, Mathematics<br />GPA in Major: 3.99, 3.97<br />Overall GPA: 3.98<br />Length of Degree: 4 years<br />Position in Class: Top<br />Type of Student: Asian male<br /><br />GRE Scores : (old)<br />Q: 800 (92%)<br />V: 700 (96%)<br />W: 3.0 (15%)<br />P: 990 (94%)<br /><br />Research Experience : 1. Accelerator Experiment(1 year, 1 paper), 2. Particle Theory(1 year, 1 paper)<br /><br />Independent Study: 1. String Theory(1 year, studied Polchinski, Kiritsis under supervision of a professor) <br />                           2. Mathematical Physics(1 semester, studied second half of Nakahara under supervision of a math professor)<br /><br />Awards/Honors/Recognitions: 1. $50,000/year for 4 years in undergrad from some private foundation 2.Phi Beta Kappa member<br /><br />Special Bonus Points: Have taken all first-year physics grad courses(QM(2), E&amp;M, Stat Mech), and all hep grad courses(QFT(3), GR(2), Pheno(2), String(1))  + algebraic topology, and the math independent study is equivalent to algebraic topology + differentiable manifold + alpha). Got 4 strong letters from my research, independent study advisors.<br /><br /><br />Applying to Where: all string theory, quantum gravity<br /><br /><span style="color: #FF0000">Princeton - Physics - HEP Theory (rejected via e-mail, 2/19)</span><br /><span style="color: #FF0000">Stanford - Physics - HEP Theory (rejected via e-mail, 2/17)</span><br /><span style="color: #FF0000">Harvard - Physics - HEP Theory (rejected via e-mail(I asked the result), 2/27)</span><br /><span style="color: #FF0000">MIT - Physics - HEP Theory (rejected via e-mail, 2/18)</span><br /><span style="color: #FF0000">UCSB - Physics - HEP Theory (rejected via e-mail, 2/24)</span><br /><span style="color: #40FF00">UC Berkeley - Physics - HEP Theory (accepted via e-mail, 2/23)</span><br /><span style="color: #FF0000">Caltech - Physics - HEP Theory (rejected via e-mail, 2/23)</span><br /><span style="color: #00FF00">Stony Brook - Physics - HEP Theory (accepted via e-mail, 1/18)(&gt;$26,000 TA)</span><br />Rutgers - Physics - HEP Theory<br /><span style="color: #BFFF00">U of Michigan - Physics - HEP Theory (wait-listed via e-mail, 2/22)</span><br />UPENN - Physics - HEP Theory<br />UCSD - Physics - HEP Theory<br /><span style="color: #00FF00">UCSC - Physics - HEP Theory (accepted via e-mail, 2/20)(~$30,000 including $10,000 Regents' Fellowship)</span></div>

Otherwise, about &gt;100 (2 year old score)<br /><br />Research Experience: 1 summer at a national lab, about one year of a particle experiments(1 UROP)<br />Publication: no journal but some online conference proceeding kind of thing<br /><br />Awards/Honors/Recognitions: a lot of small and few-grands-worth scholarships <br /><br />Pertinent Activities or Jobs: none<br /><br />Any Miscellaneous Accomplishments that Might Help:<br /><br />Special Bonus Points: grad classes, possibly postitive LOR (?)<br /><br />Any Other Info That Shows Up On Your App and Might Matter: a previous very very crappy university degree&amp;transcript from Abroad, then 2 years at a community college, 2 years at home US university,. a summer class at a different university on an uncommon topic in undergraduate curriculum<br /><br />Applying to Where:<br />Univ. Minnesota Twin-Cities: <span style="color: #008000"> Accepted Jan 28th </span><br />Stony Brook : <span style="color: #008000"> Accepted Jan 20th. 500 people applied </span> <br />New York University: <span style="color: #008000"> Informally Accepted Jan 28nd by e-mail. Funding info to come mid Feb: a four-years fellowship. TA is optional and pay additionally. ! </span> <br />Univ. Pittsburgh  <span style="color: #008000"> Accepted Feb 05 by e-mail. first year fellowship  </span> <br />Boston University   <span style="color: #008000"> Accepted by e-mail Feb 11.</span><br />CMU   Feb 05  wait-listed by e-mail.<br /><br />Brown: <span style="color: #BF8000">rejected for PhD, accepted for paid master</span><br /><br />*recommendation: I recommend future students to choose LOR providers who seem to think highly of you (even unreasonably high) and who believe that you can get into [the kind of your dream schools or better]. Show potential providers your profile and ask them what do they predict of the apps outcome, where should you apply, etc.. to probe their opinions of you<br /><br />I was getting LORs from who know me the most but in hindsight, that is not automatically a good strategy. if prof A knows you personally well but think of you as an ordinarily good student, while prof B knows you less but somehow get the impression that you are the best of the class, then B is a better provider.</div>

Took a year off after undergrad helping high schoolers and working for disability resources at local uni.<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Any Miscellaneous Accomplishments that Might Help:</span> Medical issues had an impact on academic performance, upward trend in grades. Minority.<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Any Other Info That Shows Up On Your App and Might Matter: </span> Helps to publish in your area of interest I guess.<br /><br />Applying to Where: Overall interest was in gravity, relativity, and cosmology (theory and computation).<br /><br />Caltech - Physics - <span style="color: #008000"><span style="font-weight: bold">Accepted</span> 2/19 (website).  $32k</span><br />Maryland - Physics - <span style="color: #BF0000"><span style="font-weight: bold">Rejected</span> 2/19 (website).  </span><br />PennState - Physics - <span style="color: #008000"><span style="font-weight: bold">Accepted</span> 2/12 (email).  $27k+.</span> <br />Montana State - Physics - <span style="color: #008000"><span style="font-weight: bold">Accepted</span> 1/29 (website).</span> <br /><br />Chicago - Astronomy &amp; Astrophysics - <span style="color: #008000"><span style="font-weight: bold">Accepted</span> 1/26 (phone). $35k/yr</span><br />Cornell - Astronomy &amp; Astrophysics - <span style="color: #BF0000"><span style="font-weight: bold">Rejected</span> 2/13 (email).</span><br /><br />NSF Fellowship - <span style="color: #008000"><span style="font-weight: bold">Received</span> 3/31. (E/E, E/E, E/E)</span><br />Ford Fellowship - <span style="color: #008000"><span style="font-weight: bold">Received</span> 3/23.</span><br /><br /><span style="font-style: italic"> Update 2/20: That sums up my application year, just waiting on fellowship results.  Ifelt confident on the NSF, even my well-known advisor said she felt I had a good chance at getting it.  Back in December I imagined acceptance from Cornell (astro), PennState (physics), and Montana State (physics).  I felt like I was an automatic rejection from Caltech, UChicago, and Maryland.  This goes to show how much you can misjudge your application.</span><br /><br /><span style="font-style: italic"> Update 4/6:  Not to sound too pretentious, but I would've been very surprised if I didn't at least get an honorable mention on the NSF.  I was that confident (ended up getting three E/E's ratings).  Research is essential here.  Same with LORs.  In the fall I feared my current advisor's LOR wasn't going to be spectacular, so 1-2 months before requesting it I really pushed my research.  I think doing that really left a good impression on her.  I sacrificed a good grade in the grad quantum course I was taking with this tactic.  In summary, it's all about research and LORs.  The exams are just to stamp you with a number to make the committees' jobs easier. </span></div>

This ended sooner than I was hoping...<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Undergrad Institution</span>: Top 20 Overall / Top 10 in Physics / grae's school  <img class="smilies" src="./images/smilies/icon_razz.gif" alt=":P" title="Razz" /> <br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Major(s)</span>: Physics<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Minor(s)</span>: Computer Science<br bold">Length of Degree</span>: 4<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Position in Class</span>: Close to average, but probably below average<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Type of bold">V</span>: 156 (73%)<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">W</span>: 5.0 (93%)<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">P</span>: 800 (71%)<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Research 4 author paper<br />(3) Project in field of interest (junior + senior year)<br />(4) Good REU also in field of interest (summer following junior year) --- one co-authored paper submitted after I think my personal statement was well written with clear intentions.<br />(2) I know what I want to study in grad school and already have worked on two projects in that field.<br />(3) Two of my recommendation letters have already got me into two REU programs, so they can't be too bad.<br />(4) I've met a lot of people at AAS.<br />(5) I have a somewhat direct connection to someone at University of Arizona.<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Any Other Info That Shows Up On Your App and Might Matter</span>:<br />(1) Clear Downward Trend in GPA (two worst semesters came Junior Year)<br />(2) I have taken a difficult course load, but not unusually difficult. I don't think this will play too much of a role in vindicating me.<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Applying to Where</span>: (in order of application deadline!)<br />All for Theoretical / Computational<br /><span style="color: #BA0000"><span style="text-decoration: underline">University of California - Berkeley</span> - Astronomy - Rejected 2/19</span><br /><span style="color: #00AB00"><span style="text-decoration: underline">University of Maryland - College Park</span> - Astronomy - Accepted 1/21 by Email ($26.9K/yr w/TA)</span><br /><span style="color: #BA0000"><span style="text-decoration: underline">Harvard University</span> - Astronomy - Rejected 2/27</span><br /><span style="color: #00AB00"><span style="text-decoration: underline">University of California - Los Angeles</span> - Astronomy - Accepted 2/3 by Phone ($38K 1st yr, $29K 2nd yr --- for TA or RA)</span><br /><span style="color: #00AB00"><span style="text-decoration: underline">University of Arizona</span> - Astronomy - Accepted 1/20 by Phone ($30.2K/yr w/RA + $2.5K for Research Expenses)</span><br /><span style="color: #BA0000"><span style="text-decoration: underline">California Institute of Technology</span> - Astronomy - Rejected 2/17</span><br /><span style="color: #BA0000"><span style="text-decoration: underline">University of Washington</span> - Astronomy - Rejected 3/6</span><br /><span style="color: #BA0000"><span style="text-decoration: underline">University of California - Santa Cruz</span> - Astronomy - Rejected 2/20</span><br /><span style="color: #BA0000"><span style="text-decoration: underline">University of Chicago</span> - Astronomy - Rejected 2/9</span><br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Take Away These Points</span>:<br />The worst part of my application is GPA-related, so there's not much to learn here.<br />Grades won't get you into grad school alone, but you still need to meet some loose threshold before they start to consider you based on research + rec letters. That threshold varies from person to person and place to place,<br />but is undoubtedly higher at the better, more difficult-to-get-into places and probably less loose if you are applying for theory.<br /><br />So..., get good grades -- especially junior year. That counts the most. Even if you don't have the best GPA entering junior year, you can make it up junior year.<br />Of course, you need to do research too, so... <br />In the end, you always need to be looking for the right balance between courses and research.<br /><br />On the flipside, the University of Arizona might have been the best research fit (at the very least, top two) out of all of the places I applied -- even the ones where I was rejected. So even in my case, research experience and skills are extremely important.<br /><br />Also, don't get all of your advice from this website. Talk to your advisor(s)!  <img class="smilies" src="./images/smilies/icon_biggrin.gif" alt=":D" title="Very Happy" /><br /><br /><br /><span style="font-style: italic">One More Edit:</span><br /><span style="color: #00AB00">NSF Graduate Research Fellowship --  Awarded</span> <img class="smilies" src="./images/smilies/icon_smile.gif" alt=":-)" title="Smile" /><br />The reviews cited the strength of having recommendations from three researchers at different institutions, having co-authored publications and also conference presentations, the familiarity with the literature in the proposed research, and having leadership positions in two clubs as key reasons for offering the award.</div>

Miscellaneous Accomplishments that Might Help: While in college I was super active in promoting social justice in terms of race and religious pluralism, and also took on a lot of non-academic leadership roles. Also, I'm currently a finalist for the Fulbright Travel Fellowship.<br /><br />Special Bonus Points: I'm not quite sure how to phrase this without coming off conceited, but I try to be friendly and earnest in my interactions with people, which translates to easily creating positive relationships with my mentors and coming off as charismatic in groups and to strangers. My three recommenders all like me a lot, and my NASA mentor was very impressed with the quality of my work. Additionally, the schmoozing I did at AAS this year and at departments' open houses was definitely instrumental to some of my admission decisions. One of my recommenders is a professor at my top choice school. I'm also assuming that the fact that I'm a woman of color with good research experience and decent grades is not inconsequential to how people read my application.<br /><br />Any Other Info That Shows Up On Your App and Might Matter: My school has active grade deflation. Also, I studied physics abroad at a UK school and got good grades. In all my application, I talked a lot about how I wanted to apply my education in becoming a leader, either in the context of education or NASA missions. When it was relevant, I went into detail about my time with NASA, my eagerness to explore new topics, and my fluency in Spanish (re: Yale's program with the Universidad de Chile).<br /><br />Applying to Where: <br />All are either PhDs in astronomy or the equivalent that the school carries unless specified, and I'm wasn't incredibly picky about what topic I'll pursue (just no heliophysics, solar system astronomy, fluid dynamics-heavy projects, or ISM).<br />Asterisks mark top choices; my safety was CUNY.<br /><br />In order of preference:<br />Columbia University* <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected 2/26 via email</span><br />University of Washington Seattle* <span style="color: #FFBF00">Wait-listed over phone 2/25, phone interview 2/18</span><br />Yale University <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected 2/23 via email</span><br />Boston University* <span style="color: #408040">Accepted 1/26 via phone call, visited</span><br />University of Maryland at College Park*<br />University of Colorado Boulder <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected 2/13 via email</span><br />Arizona State University <span style="color: #408040">Accepted 2/3 via email, visited</span><br />University of Minnesota <span style="color: #FFBF00">Wait-listed over email 1/29, invited to visit</span><br />University of California Riverside, Physics and Astronomy<br />CUNY Graduate Center, Physics <span style="color: #408040">Casually accepted over email 1/30, withdrew</span></div>

																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																			       <p class="author"><a href="./viewtopic.php?p=48795#p48795"><span class="imageset icon_post_target" title="Post">Post</span></a><span class="responsive-hide">by <strong><a href="./memberlist.php?mode=viewprofile&amp;u=19965" class="username">irezumidragon</a></strong> &raquo; </span>Sat Jan 31, 2015 6:52 pm </p>



																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																						        <div class="content">Undergrad Institution: Big State School, Top 20 in Phys/Astro<br />Major(s): Astronomy, Physics<br />Minor(s): n/a<br />GPA in Major: 3.55<br />Overall GPA: 3.66<br />Length of Degree: 4<br />Position in Class: Average<br />Type of Student: Domestic Female<br /><br />GRE Scores : <br />Q: 157 (69%)<br />V: 164 (93%)<br />W: 4.5 (80%)<br />P: 640 (38%)   <img class="smilies" src="./images/smilies/icon_neutral.gif" alt=":|" title="Neutral" /> <br /><br /><br />Research Experience: Two summer internships with Lockheed Martin (engineering/instrumentation in the first one, solar physics in the second one). 3.5 years research at my university, 1.5 in ISM astrochemistry/spectroscopy, 2 in IGM/Circumgalactic and AGN topics. One submitted AJ first author paper, one first author paper in prep. Presented poster at Jan. 2014 AAS, was a co-author on a Hubble Observing Proposal. <br /><br />Awards/Honors/Recognitions: Magna Cum Laude for honors thesis, Phi Beta Kappa honors fraternity scholarship<br /><br />Pertinent Activities or Jobs: Paper grader for 4 different astro courses, occasional volunteer at campus observatory open house, casual math/physics/astro tutoring/helproom<br /><br />Any Miscellaneous Accomplishments that Might Help: On-site observing experience at Apache Point Observatory (3.5m), certified on university's 24&quot; telescope. <br /><br />Special Bonus Points: Three grad classes<br /><br />Any Other Info That Shows Up On Your App and Might Matter: Not really? This is my second app cycle after nothing but waitlists that ended in rejections last year, so I emphasized how much I have reflected upon my desire to go to graduate school and my SOP feels much more mature this year.<br /><br />Applying to Where:  All schools were astronomy programs unless astro was encapsulated in physics<br /><br />Johns Hopkins -         <span style="color: #FF0000">rejected 4/9</span> (They waitlisted me last year, I thought maybe applying again I'd have a shot)<br />Penn State -              <span style="color: #0040FF">waitlisted 1/29</span><br />Ohio State -              <span style="color: #0040FF">waitlisted 1/5, all slots filled no admission 4/11</span> <br />Michigan Ann Arbor - <span style="color: #0040FF">waitlisted 3/31</span><br />Michigan State -        <span style="color: #00BF40">Accepted 1/19</span> <span style="color: #BF00FF">Declined 3/30</span><br />Wisconsin Madison -   <span style="color: #0040FF">waitlisted 3/12</span> <span style="color: #00BF40">Accepted 4/13---Will Attend</span><br />U. Minnesota -           <span style="color: #0040FF">waitlisted 1/29</span> <span style="color: #00BF40">Accepted 3/28</span> <br />UT Austin -                <span style="color: #0040FF">waitlisted 2/02, all slots filled no admission 4/14</span><br />New Mexico State -    <span style="color: #00BF40">Accepted 2/13</span>  <span style="color: #BF00FF">Declined 2/17</span><br />U. Arizona -              <span style="color: #FF0000">rejected 1/23</span><br />Arizona State -          <span style="color: #FF0000">rejected 4/7</span><br />UC Irvine -                <span style="color: #FF0000">rejected 4/6</span><br />UC Riverside -           <span style="color: #00BF40">Accepted 2/11 Chancellor's Distinguished Fellowship </span> <span style="color: #BF00FF">Declined 4/7</span><br /><br />My main takeaways after going through this god forsaken process twice are: <br />1) Connections are very important. Every school where I was accepted had very tangible ties to one or more of my letter writers. <br />2) The PGRE was more important than they say. My first cycle I was applying with a 27% and was rejected everywhere. My second cycle, I managed to pry out of my department that they had an unspoken cut-off of around 40% (a top 20 program). By getting to that floor-level score, I was admitted to all schools &quot;below&quot; the tier of my undergrad, and waitlisted at schools that were in a similar tier. <br />3) Be sure your letter writers have worked with you recently, are friendly/like you, and are not spacey (had an emeritus prof write one for cycle 1 and found out later that he writes terrible letters). If you can, poll around and see if anyone knows the quality of your letter writers before you ask that person to write for you.<br />4) I don't know if it had any bearing on anything, but my SOP for cycle 2 was trimmed to absolutely professional. No personal anecdotes, just my research experience, what I'd been doing since graduation, my grad school research interests, and what I wanted to do with my career.</div>

																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																													       <p class="author"><a href="./viewtopic.php?p=48796#p48796"><span class="imageset icon_post_target" title="Post">Post</span></a><span class="responsive-hide">by <strong><a href="./memberlist.php?mode=viewprofile&amp;u=19966" class="username">pillow47</a></strong> &raquo; </span>Sat Jan 31, 2015 7:13 pm </p>



																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																        <div class="content">Undergrad Institution: Elite LAC (strong reputation for STEMs fields, particularly physics) <br />Major(s): Physics, Math <br />Minor(s): Econ? (I don't know if it counts as a minor or its equivalence...)<br />GPA in Major: Physics: 3.95+ , math: 4.00<br />Overall GPA: 3.90+ <br />Length of Degree: 4<br />Position in Class: Top/near top <br />Type of Student: International Chinese male <br /><br />GRE Scores : (revised or old version?)<br />Q: 168<br />V: 166<br />W: 4.5<br />P: 990 (I didn't start studying for GRE until very late (like a week ago before the exam), but I powered through a book called <span style="font-style: italic">Conquering Physics GRE</span> in 4 days. And it gave me a nice result. I highly recommend this book for cramming, if you ever plan to just cram...But really,,, don't cram!)<br /><br /><br />Research Experience: 1 summer computational electrodynamics, 1 summer computational solid state, 1 summer + 1 year experimental magnetism, 5 weeks biophysics. No publications, no conferences. <br /><br />Awards/Honors/Recognitions: all departmental, no importance. chemistry in sophomore year, physics in junior year, math in senior year. (guess it means I'm well-rounded?)<br /><br />Pertinent Activities or Jobs: Tutor for a CS class. Grader for many physics classes. <br /><br />Any Miscellaneous Accomplishments that Might Help: <br />a) I almost took all physics courses offered at my school and did three independent studies in addition. Well-trained in math, somewhat well-trained in chemistry and CS. <br />b) Did quite well on basically all physics classes I took. (e.g. scored 100 on the final of a very hard class, while the class average was ~60). Performances like these might matter if the recommenders brought them up in letters. <br />c) Actually did something useful in our lab, though not publishable, but still something worth being proud of <img class="smilies" src="./images/smilies/icon_wink.gif" alt=";)" title="Wink" /> <br /><br />Special Bonus Points:<br />a) All my recommenders know me very well and seem to like me!  <img class="smilies" src="./images/smilies/icon_biggrin.gif" alt=":D" title="Very Happy" /> . My research advisor has many connections in the field. <br />b) I injured my hand the day before I got into Stanford. I think it gave me good karma.  <img class="smilies" src="./images/smilies/icon_mrgreen.gif" alt=":mrgreen:" title="Mr. Green" /> <br /><br />Any Other Info That Shows Up On Your App and Might Matter: I think I showed lots of passion for physics (which, really, is the most important thing!!) <br /><br />Applying to Where: (All CME and CMT. All physics department, except for Stanford, which is Applied Physics)<br /><br />Princeton-<span style="color: #00BF00">Admitted 2/19</span><br />Stanford-<span style="color: #00BF00">Admitted 1/31</span><br />UCSB-<span style="color: #00BF00">Likely letter 1/14, Admitted 1/21</span><br />MIT-<span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected 2/18</span><br />Harvard-<span style="color: #00BF00">Admitted 2/17</span><br />Caltech-<span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected</span><br />Chicago-<span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected</span><br />Yale-<span style="color: #0000BF">Waitlisted-Declined</span><br />Cornell-<span style="color: #00BF00">Admitted 2/10</span><br />Berkeley-<span style="color: #00BF00">Admitted</span><br />UIUC-<span style="color: #00BF00">Admitted 1/23</span><br />UCSD-<span style="color: #00BF00">Admitted 1/26</span><br />Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry-<span style="color: #008000">Admitted instantly (for chillness and awesomeness)</span><br /><br />------------<br />Some afterthoughts and comments: <br />I don't know why I didn't get into MIT. It's still a mystery to me. Before the application, I thought it was a safety school for me. There is a MIT prof who is an ex-member of our research group at college. My research interests match with his almost perfectly. My recommender was his college thesis advisor. I thought MIT was the school where professors' opinions are the most important in the admission process, so I was pretty sure I would get in... Afterwards when I visited Harvard, I went to MIT to visit this professor. He said he never saw my profile. Quite odd that MIT turned me down in the first round given my GPA and test scores. Rather a unpredictable process, indeed. <br /><br />Then there's Caltech and Chicago. I was pretty sure I wouldn't get in, and I didn't. When I was applying to schools, Princeton was my #1 choice, so I pulled down their website and basically wrote my statement of purpose according to the Princeton profs. For every other school, I changed a fews words. e.g. Princeton to MIT, some Princeton prof to some MIT prof. For pretty much very every other school, it worked out okay. But for Caltech and Chicago, I felt the inconsistency in the SoP even when I was writing it, because the department focus is so different between Princeton and Caltech and Chicago. I would say I'm interested in XX in the first paragraph only to find out that &quot;Oh Shoot, Caltech/Chicago doesn't have any prof who does XX, so let me stick some random prof that does YY, because I really don't want to change my main paragraph cuz it's the 12th SoP I'm writing in one day.&quot; <br />So take-home lesson: Give lots care/time to every single SoP, because the departmental difference across schools can be significant!!<br /><br />Wish everyone a fruitful grad school career.  <img class="smilies" src="./images/smilies/icon_mrgreen.gif" alt=":mrgreen:" title="Mr. Green" /> <br /><br />______________________________________________</div>

Also second author on a paper in Optics Express, in review at time of application.<br /><br />REU at UCLA after sophomore year in a computational project related to free electron lasers.<br /><br />REU in materials science at Cornell doing domain wall measurements in nanowires. This went really well I think.<br /><br />Awards/Honors/Recognitions: Sigma Pi Sigma, some random stuff<br /><br />Pertinent Activities or Jobs: SPS board member, grader, TA, tutor<br /><br />Any Miscellaneous Accomplishments that Might Help: Nah<br /><br />Special Bonus Points: Recommenders have some connections to schools<br /><br />Any Other Info That Shows Up On Your App and Might Matter: Can drink a gallon of milk in 45 min.<br /><br />Applying to Where (All Physics, condensed matter experiment unless otherwise noted):<br /><br />US News Top 10<br />MIT - <span style="color: #BF0000">Rejected 2/18</span> - Definitely expecting this. MIT looks at your first semester senior transcripts and my senioritis set in early.<br />Stanford (Applied, nanoscience and quantum engineering) - <span style="color: #40FF00">Accepted 1/31! 3k/month for three quarters, plus summer option. 2/18 fellowship 6k/yr for first 5 years, plus 1500 this summer and 4k next summer</span> <br />Berkeley - <span style="color: #BF0000">Rejected 3/12</span><br />Harvard -<span style="color: #BF0000"> Rejected early March</span><br />Cal Tech - <span style="color: #BF0000">Rejected 2/23</span><br />Cornell (Applied)- <span style="color: #00FF00">Accepted 2/11! Fellowship for 29k/9 months</span><br />Chicago -<span style="color: #BF0000"> Rejected early March</span><br />UCSB - <span style="color: #BF0000">Rejected 2/24</span> - Not that it necessarily made a difference but I forgot to report my GRE scores<br /><br />Top 20<br />Columbia (Applied) - <span style="color: #00FF00">Accepted 3/10! A little late but I'll take it. No offer yet.</span><br />Maryland - <span style="color: #BF0000">Rejected 2/18</span><br />UCLA - <span style="color: #00FF00">Accepted 2/11! Fellowship+TA/GSR 33k/first 9 months, 24k/9 after that</span><br />Johns Hopkins - <span style="color: #40FF00">Accepted 1/22! 25K/9 months TA + 8K summers</span><br /><br />Top 30<br />Minnesota - <span style="color: #40FF00">Accepted 1/28! 24K/12 months, 2 year fellowship</span><br />Rutgers - <span style="color: #00FF00">Accepted 2/6! first year fellowship 29k/10 months, plus 4k Torrey Fellowship</span><br /><br /><br />Reflection:<br />Obviously I had better luck with applied physics than physics programs. There is some discrepancy in the acceptance rate at Stanford (17% for applied, 13% regular physics) but its about 20% for each at Cornell. So it could be that applied physics programs are easier to get into, that my application is better suited for applied physics programs, coincidence, or some combination of the three.<br /><br />As advice for future applicants, I think my biggest weakness is that I didn't have a long term project at my home school. This is mostly because I couldn't find what I was interested in. So my advice is to try to find what you like as soon as possible, or at least find a lab where you fit in and really work hard at a project for a couple of years so you can get a strong letter of rec.<br /><br /><br />Good luck to everyone, this year and in the future!</div>

 <p class="author"><a href="./viewtopic.php?p=49055#p49055"><span class="imageset icon_post_target" title="Post">Post</span></a><span class="responsive-hide">by <strong><a href="./memberlist.php?mode=viewprofile&amp;u=19953" class="username">phizzles</a></strong> &raquo; </span>Sat Feb 14, 2015 12:35 am </p>



																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																				   <div class="content"><blockquote><div><cite>phizzles wrote:</cite>______________________________________________<br />Undergrad Institution: Big State, decent physics rep (I'll be more specific about everything after I get in more places...I am paranoid)<br />Major(s): Physics, Math<br />Minor(s):<br />GPA in Major: ~3.9<br />Overall GPA: ~3.8<br />Length of Degree: 4<br />Position in Class: top 10%<br />Type of Student: Domestic<br /><br />GRE Scores : <br />Q: 170<br />V: 166<br />W: 5<br />P: ~900<br /><br /><br />Research Experience: 2 REUs, both at top 20 schools. Bounced around labs at home institution, writing a thesis in CM.<br /><br />Awards/Honors/Recognitions: Sigma Pi Sigma, some random stuff<br /><br />Pertinent Activities or Jobs: SPS board member, grader, TA, tutor<br /><br />Any Miscellaneous Accomplishments that Might Help: Nah<br /><br />Special Bonus Points: Recommenders have some connections to schools<br /><br />Any Other Info That Shows Up On Your App and Might Matter: Can drink a gallon of milk in 45 min.<br /><br />Applying to Where (All Physics, condensed matter experiment unless otherwise noted):<br /><br />Berkeley<br />Cal Tech<br />Chicago<br />Columbia (Applied)<br />Cornell (Applied)- <span style="color: #00FF00">Accepted 2/11! First year fellowship 29k/9 months</span><br />Harvard<br />Johns Hopkins - <span style="color: #40FF00">Accepted 1/22! 25K/9 months TA + 8K summers</span><br />Maryland<br />Minnesota - <span style="color: #40FF00">Accepted 1/28! 24K/12 months, 2 year fellowship</span><br />MIT<br />Rutgers - <span style="color: #00FF00">Accepted 2/6! first year fellowship 29k/10 months, plus 4k Torrey Fellowship</span><br />Stanford (Applied, nanoscience and quantum engineering) - <span style="color: #40FF00">Accepted 1/31! 3k/month for three quarters, plus summer option</span><br />UCLA - <span style="color: #00FF00">Accepted 2/11! Funding info to come.</span><br />UCSB<br /><br /><br />Reflection:<br />So out of boredom I compiled the results of applicants who posted on this forum between 2011-2014 who are similar to me: students at big but well known state schools in the US with a physics gpa between 3.75-3.95, PGRE between 750-950, and at least one year of research (I excluded plasma physics and astro applicants because the programs are so different). There were 22 such cases. This isn't enough to make any real conclusions but it can at least serve as a bit of guidance for future applicants. I found that these students, on average, got into 33% of schools ranked 1-7 by US News, 51% of those ranked 9-16, and 90% of those ranked 18-30. There was very little, if any, correlation between gpa, gre, and research with better results (but  this is such a small sample and there are so many other factors, that it's possible such a correlation exists but just isn't obvious). Only 2 people got into all schools they applied to. Only 2 people didn't get into any 1-16 ranked schools, and no one was rejected everywhere.<br /><br />The take home message for future applicants with these or similar qualifications is to try and save up your money this next summer to apply to as many good schools as possible. You have a realistic chance anywhere, but if you only apply to 2 or 3 top schools you have a realistic chance of having to settle on somewhere else (not that that would be the end of the world). On the flip side, don't get too attached to any one school, because no acceptances are guaranteed.<br /><br />Good luck to everyone, this year and in the future!</div></blockquote></div>

																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																		         <div class="content"><span style="font-weight: bold">Undergrad Institution</span>: Large state school with a reputation for physics research<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Major(s)</span>: Astrophysics<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Minor(s)</span>: Mathematics<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">GPA in Major</span>: 3.93<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Overall GPA</span>: 3.85<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Length of Degree</span>: 4.5 years<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Position in Class</span>: Top<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Type of Student</span>: Domestic female<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">GRE Scores </span>: <br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Q</span>: 157 (67%)<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">V</span>: 159 (83%)<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">W</span>: 5 (93%)<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">P</span>: 680 (47%)<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Research Experience</span>: Three years of research at my home institution. This included a lengthy research project with observing time, as well as instrumentation work for various astronomy projects. One summer at an international astronomy research institute. <br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Awards/Honors/Recognitions</span>: Space Grant, Undergraduate Research Award<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Pertinent Activities or Jobs</span>: Treasurer for SPS. Telescope operator at campus observatory. Telescope operator for large scale telescope. <br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Any Miscellaneous Accomplishments that Might Help</span>:<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Special Bonus Points</span>: One of my letter writers is well known, particularly at some of the institutions I've applied to. We also have collaborators at several schools I've applie dto as well. <br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Any Other Info That Shows Up On Your App and Might Matter</span>:<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Applying to Where</span>:<br /><br />University of Arizona - Astronomy <span style="color: #008000">Accepted</span><br />University of Iowa - Physics and Astronomy <span style="color: #008000">Accepted</span><br />UW Madison - Astronomy  <span style="color: #008000">Accepted</span><br />Harvard - Astronomy <span style="color: #008000">Accepted</span><br />University of Washington -- Astronomy <span style="color: #0000FF">Interviewed -- Offered spot in physics department</span> -- <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected from astro</span><br />UC Santa Barbara - Astronomy <span style="color: #0000FF">Contacted letter writer</span> -- <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected</span><br />University of Virginia -- Astronomy <span style="color: #0000FF">Interviewed</span> -- <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected</span><br />University of Maryland -- Astronomy <span style="color: #0000FF">Unofficial waitlist</span> -- <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected</span><br />Boston University -- Astronomy <span style="color: #0000FF">Unofficial waitlist</span> -- <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected</span><br />UCLA - Astronomy <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected 2/5</span><br />CU Boulder - Astronomy <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected 2/13</span><br />Caltech - Astronomy <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected 2/17</span><br />UC Berkeley - Astronomy <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected 2/19</span><br />Arizona State - Astronomy <span style="color: #FF0000">Rejected</span><br /><br />I think the biggest downfall of my application was definitely my GRE scores. I think I would have been a competitive applicant otherwise, and I'd be willing to bet that many of my rejections from places like Caltech and UC Berkeley were due to insufficient GRE scores. That being said, I do think that more and more universities are beginning to place less emphasis on GRE scores and are instead vastly more interested in your research experience. Connections are definitely not enough. Pay attention to how many grad students the advisor you're interested in working with already has -- they might not be able to justify taking on more students. If possible, attend the AAS winter meeting. I talked to a substantial number of professors and admission committee members at the meeting which may have helped seal the deal in some cases. <br /><br />All in all, I think research is KEY. From what I've gathered, stellar GRE scores and a high GPA on their own will not get you into grad school. You need to have research experience for physics/astro programs. If you have all three, I'd say you're very competitive and have a very good shot of getting into top programs. But again, as long as you have research experience, I would suggest applying to a wide range of schools. Just my two cents.</div>

Two summer research at prominent universities (one is Ivy, another is a reputed university outside US), one year of research in my school, no publication, no talks. <br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Awards/Honors/Recognitions</span>: Scholarships, a Medal in International Physics Olympiad, bla bla..<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Pertinent Activities or Jobs</span>: Was tutor after high school..don't know if it actually matters<br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Any Miscellaneous Accomplishments that Might Help</span>: I enjoy eating, especially delicious foods. <br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Special Bonus Points</span>: Recommendation letters are probably strong.<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Any Other Info That Shows Up On Your App and Might Matter</span>: Not that I remember.<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold">Applying to Where</span>:<br /><br /><span style="text-decoration: underline">Stanford</span> - Physics - Astrophysics- <span style="color: #8000FF">Rejected</span><br /><span style="text-decoration: underline">Yale</span> - Physics - Astrophysics - <span style="color: #8000FF">Rejected</span><br /><span style="text-decoration: underline">UChicago</span> - Physics - Astrophysics - <span style="color: #8000FF">Rejected</span><br /><span style="text-decoration: underline">Carnegie Mellon</span> - Physics - Astrophysics - <span style="color: #8000FF">Rejected</span><br /><span style="text-decoration: underline">UPitt</span> - Physics - Astrophysics -<span style="color: #BFFF40">Waitlisted</span>--&gt;<span style="color: #8000FF">Rejected</span><br /><span style="text-decoration: underline">Penn State</span> - Physics - Astrophysics - <span style="color: #8000FF">Rejected</span><br /><span style="text-decoration: underline">Ohio State</span> - Physics - Astrophysics -<span style="color: #BFFF40">Waitlisted</span>--&gt; <span style="color: #8000FF">Rejected</span><br /><br />______________________________________________<br />Life is hard. I thought my application was quite strong. The only thing that was lacking was publication (so, the take home message is that if you don't have a publication, don't ever think of any school as a safety). My professors were actually advising me to apply to more top tier schools. Even sh*ts like UPitt and Carnegie Mellon haven't replied yet. I thought I am actually overqualified for Yale (what do they think of themselves, they are Ivy league, I know that, but what else?). Actually, applying to Yale was a mistake - I should have applied to more schools whose focus is more on hard core (not sure if that word is relevant) research like UTexas and some UCs. Well, since Penn State and Ohio State have already started sending out offers, I think my chances this year is close to nil. Thinking of going to some remote part of the world and teaching English, Science and Mathematics. May be I will be able to transform life of some..at least I got a privilege of undergraduate education. Let's see where I will take myself!</div>

(Of course, this may not apply to theorists) <br />* Working with one established PI for a long time helps. You can possibly publish something, or at least get a good rec-letter.<br />* In supplementary material, show that you can actually understand and define what you did in the lab. Do not just say &quot;I have first author papers, so I am super-smart.&quot;</div>

Accepted 2/17</span><br /><br />----------------------------------------------------------------<br /><br />Looking back at my undergrad career and analyzing the posts uploaded in the forum (yes, I've studied admission profiles back from ~2012..creep much?), I have a few words of advice, <span style="font-weight: bold">especially for prospective theorists</span> (this applies to those who are aiming for top 10-20 schools):<br /><br />1. All other things being equal, theory is much harder to get in than experiment. I haven't seen many acceptances among theory applicants here, despite having fantastic stats. This has less to do with the discrepancy in the stats of applicants than the very nature of the field. There are fewer professors in theory, and as far as I know, each professor only takes in 1-2 grad students at the mos (at least ~900). Although there are exceptional cases, these are rarer for applicants in theory than in experiment (where there seems to be more leeway; but they seem to value research experience more). Sure, PGRE may not reflect your physics abilwho got into top schools, where many with first-author pubs were rejected. In my opinion, these schools look for applicants who will be a good fit to their department, whether through the SOP, rec. letters, etc.<br /><br />4. Chill. There are plenty of good places and professors where you can study theoretical physics. Studying Ads/CFT correspondence at Princeton may sound really cool, but that's just a part of your life. IMO, having fun and meeting/dating people (i.e. those who actually think &quot;lagrangian&quot; isn't a word) is equally important, if not more, than the actual academic work you do. So, work hard and play hard guys, and to those applying this year, good luck wherever you all end up!</div>

Rejected</span> <br /><br />Overall, delighted with Cornell. I had become disillusioned with the whole process and was planning to go Cambridge or Oxford,which is why I only applied to three places in the US, but it turned out pretty well.</div>

               <div class="notice">

<script>
 // Load GPT asynchronously
 var googletag = googletag || {};
 googletag.cmd = googletag.cmd || [];
 (function() {
   var gads = document.createElement('script');
   gads.async = true;
   var useSSL = 'https:' == document.location.protocol;
   gads.src = (useSSL ? 'https:' : 'http:') +
       '//www.googletagservices.com/tag/js/gpt.js';
   var node = document.getElementsByTagName('script')[0];
   node.parentNode.insertBefore(gads, node);
 })();

</script>


<script>

 // GPT slots
 var gptAdSlots = [];
 googletag.cmd.push(function() {

   // Define a size mapping object. The first parameter to addSize is
   // a viewport size, while the second is a list of allowed ad sizes.
   var mapping = googletag.sizeMapping().

   // Accepts both common mobile banner formats
   addSize([320, 200], [[320, 50], [320, 100]]).

   // Landscape tablet
   addSize([800, 200], [728, 90]).build();

   // Define the GPT slot
   gptAdSlots[0] = googletag.defineSlot('/51894415/pgre_bottom_responsive', [320, 50], 'ad-slot').
       defineSizeMapping(mapping).
       addService(googletag.pubads());
   googletag.pubads().setTargeting("test","responsive");

   // Start ad fetching
   googletag.enableServices();
 });
</script>






<br />
<div id="ad-slot" style="margin: 0 auto; float: none; display: block; text-align:center;">
   <script>
     googletag.cmd.push(function() {
       googletag.display('ad-slot');
     });
   </script>
</div>
